lesson.name: Lesson 4.10: Graphing a Function Using Transformations

page.title: 4.10.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will work to graph linear functions using different types of transformations, including vertical shifts, vertical compressions, vertical stretches, and vertical reflections.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Use slope-intercept form and transformations to graph linear functions.
  • Recognize the shifts made to a parent linear function to form another linear function.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 4.10.1: Graphing Linear Functions
  • 4.10.2: Vertical Shifts
  • 4.10.2: Self Check
  • 4.10.3: Vertical Stretches and Compressions
  • 4.10.3: Self Check
  • 4.10.4: Graphing Using Transformations

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 4.10.5: Practice
  • 4.10.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 4.10.1: Graphing Linear Functions
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity



  1. Use the graphing tool above or technology outside the course, on your coordinate grid, use the slope and \(y\)-intercept of each equation to graph each equation. Use a different color for each equation.
  • \( y=3x +4\)
  • \(y=3x - 2\)
  • \(y=\frac13 x+1\)
  • \(y=-\frac13 x-3\)

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:



  1. What is the relationship between lines \(a\) and \(b\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

They are parallel lines.


  1. What is the relationship between lines \(b\) and \(d\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

They are perpendicular lines.



  1. How many vertical spaces are between lines \(a\) and \(b\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

6

page.title: 4.10.2: Vertical Shifts
page.contents:
Activity



  1. Use the graphing tool  above or technology outside the course, on the same coordinate grid, graph the following linear functions. Use a different color for each:
  • \( f(x)=x+4\)
  • \(f(x)=x+2\)
  • \(f(x)=x\)
  • \(f(x)=x-2\)
  • \(f(x)=x-4\)

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your graph to the one below:



  1. What is the slope of each line?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

1



  1. How can the parent function, \(f(x)=x\), be shifted to overlap \(f(x)=x+2\)?

Correct!

Try again.

The correct answer is Shift up 2. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. How can the parent function, \(f(x)=x\), be shifted to overlap \(f(x)=x-4\)?

Correct!

Try again.

The correct answer is Shift down 4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


  • \( f(x)=x+4\)
  • \(f(x)=x+2\)
  • \(f(x)=x\)
  • \(f(x)=x-2\)
  • \(f(x)=x-4\)

What changed with these functions? How did this change their graphs?

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:

The constant added to or subtracted from x changed. When a number was added to x, it shifted the line up that many units. When a number was subtracted from x, it shifted the line down that many units..


In \(f(x)=mx+b\), the \(b\) acts as the vertical shift. This is a type of transformation to the graph of \(f(x)=x\). The vertical shift “transforms” the parent function into another function.

page.title: 4.10.2: Self Check
page.contents: What transformation takes place from the graph of \(y=4x-3\) to \(y=4x +5\)?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: For the second function to move down, there would be a negative change. The answer is up 8.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: In \(y=mx+b\), the \(b\) describes the vertical shift. The answer is up 8.
That’s correct! Check yourself: In the two equations, the \(b\), or \(y\)-intercept of \(y=mx+b\), changes. This determines the vertical change. From –3 to 5 is a vertical shift up 8.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(y\)-intercept changing signifies a vertical change. The answer is up 8.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.10.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Vertical Shifts and \(y\)-Intercepts

In the equation \(f(x)=mx+b\):

  • \(b\) is the \(y\)-intercept of the graph and indicates the point \((0,b)\) at which the graph crosses the \(y\)-axis.
  • \(m\) is the slope of the line and indicates the vertical displacement (rise) and horizontal displacement (run) between each successive pair of points.

The \(y\)-intercept tells where the parent function, \(f(x)=x\), has shifted up or down.

Example 1:

Tell how \(f(x)=x+7\) has shifted from the parent function \(f(x)=x\).
Since \(b=7\), the \(y\)-intercept is +7, so the graph shifts up 7 from the parent function.

Example 2:

Tell how \(f(x)=x-9\) has shifted from the parent function \(f(x)=x\).
Since \(b=-9\), the \(y\)-intercept is –9, so the graph shifts down 9 from the parent function.

Try It: Vertical Shifts and \(y\)-Intercepts


Tell the shift made to \(f(x)=x\) to arrive at \(f(x)=x - 4\).

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to find the shift made to \(f(x)=x\):

Since the \(b\) of slope-intercept form is –4, this is also the \(y\)-intercept. Therefore, the graph of \(f(x)=x\) is shifted down 4 to arrive at \(f(x)=x-4\).

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.10.3: Vertical Stretches and Compressions
page.contents:
Activity





  1. Use the graphing tool above or technology outside this course to graph the following linear functions. Use a different color for each:
    1. \( f(x)=3x\)
    2. \( f(x)=2x\)
    3. \(f(x)=x\)

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:



  1. What do you notice about the slopes of lines \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) as the number gets larger?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

As the coefficient increases, the line gets steeper.





  1. Now, graph lines \(d\) and \(e\) on the same graph as \(a\)–\(c\), but use different colors.
    1. \(f(x)=\frac12 x\;\)
    2. \( f(x)=\frac13 x\;\)

Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answers:



  1. How does line \(d\) compare to line \(b\)? What can you say about the lines when \(m<1\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

As the coefficient gets smaller, the line is less steep.


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

There is a negative coefficient. This reflected the positive version of the line over the \(x\)-axis.



  1. Now graph lines \(f\), \(g\), and \(h\) on the same coordinate grid as \(a\)–\(e\), but use different colors.
    1. \( f(x)=-\frac12 x\;\)
    2. \(f(x)=-x\)
    3. \(f(x)=-2x\)

Then select the Solution button to check your work.


Compare your answer:



  1. What changed with these functions? How did this change their graphs?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

There is a negative coefficient. This reflected the positive version of the line over the x-axis


In the equation \(f(x)=mx\), the \(m\) is acting as the vertical stretch or vertical compression of the identity function. When \(m\) is negative, there is also a vertical reflection of the graph.

Multiplying the equation of \(f(x)=x\) by \(m\) stretches the graph of \(f\) by a factor of \(m\) units if \(m>1\) and compresses the graph of \(f\) by a factor of \(m\) units if \(0<m<1\). This means the larger the absolute value of \(m\), the steeper the slope.

Video: Identifying Vertical Stretches and Compressions

Watch the following video to learn more about vertical stretches and compressions.

page.title: 4.10.3: Self Check
page.contents: How does the graph of \(f(x)=\frac14 x -3\) change from the parent function, \(f(x)=x\)?

answer.answer_text: Vertical stretch of \(\frac14\), down 3
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: A slope less than 1 signifies a vertical compression. The answer is vertical compression of \(\frac14\), down 3.

answer.answer_text: Vertical compression of \(\frac14\), down 3
answer.response: That’s correct! Check yourself: The slope is \(\frac14\), which is less than 1, so there is a vertical compression. The \(y\)-intercept is –3, so there is a vertical shift down 3.

answer.answer_text: Vertical compression of \(\frac14\), up 3
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(y\)-intercept is negative. The answer is vertical compression of \(\frac14\), down 3.

answer.answer_text: Vertical stretch of \(\frac14\), left 3
answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: A slope less than 1 signifies a vertical compression, and the \(y\)-intercept gives the vertical shift. The answer is vertical compression of \(\frac14\), down 3.

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 4.10.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Transformations of Linear Functions

Given the equation of a linear function, use transformations to graph the linear function in the form \(f(x)=mx+b\).

  1. Graph \(f(x)=x\).
  2. Vertically stretch or compress the graph by a factor \(m\).
  3. Shift the graph up or down \(b\) units.

Graph \(f(x)=12x−3\) using transformations.

The equation for the function shows that \(m=12\), so the identity function is vertically compressed by 12. The equation for the function also shows that \(b=-3\), so the identity function is vertically shifted down 3 units. First, graph the identity function, and show the vertical compression as in Figure 16.

This graph shows two functions on an \((x, y)\) coordinate plane. One shows an increasing function of \(y = x\) divided by 2 that runs through the points \((0, 0)\) and \((2, 1)\). The second shows an increasing function of \(y = x\) and runs through the points \((0, 0)\) and \((1, 1)\).

Now, show the vertical shift:

This graph shows two functions on an \((x, y)\) coordinate plane. The first is an increasing function of \(y = x\) divided by 2 and runs through the points \((0, 0)\) and \((2, 1)\). The second shows an increasing function of \(y = x\) divided by 2 minus 3 and passes through the points \((0, 3)\) and \((2, -2)\). An arrow pointing downward from the first function to the second function reveals the vertical shift.

Can we sketch a graph by reversing the order of the transformations?

No. The order of the transformations follows the order of operations. When the function is evaluated at a given input, the corresponding output is calculated by following the order of operations. So, the stretch was performed before the vertical shift.

Try It: Transformations of Linear Functions


Name the transformations to go from the parent function, \(f(x)=x\), to \(f(x)=4+2x\).

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to determine the transformations:

First, the slope \(m=2\) tells that there is a vertical stretch of 2.

Next, the \(y\)-intercept is 4, so there is a vertical shift up 2.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 4.10.4: Graphing Using Transformations
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Match each equation of the linear functions with one of the lines in the given graph.


  1. \(f(x)=2x+3\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  1. \(g(x)=2x−3\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

III



  1. \(h(x)=−2x+3\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

  1. \(j(x)=\frac{1}{2}x+3\)

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

II

page.title: 4.10.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

Use the graph below to answer #1–3.

  1. Tell the shift from \(j(x)=2x-6\) to \(f(x)=2x+3\).

Correct! Up 9

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 4.10.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is up 9. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Tell the transformations from \(f(x)=2x+3\) to \(h(x)=-2x+2\).

Correct! Vertical reflection, down 1

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.10.2–4.10.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is vertical reflection, down 1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Describe the transformations made from the parent linear function to achieve \(g(x)=\frac12 x -4\). Select all that apply:

Correct! Vertical compression of \(\frac12\); Down 4

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.10.2–4.10.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are vertical compression of \(\frac12\), down 4. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What are the equations of the two lines shown? Select all that apply:

Correct! \(y=-\frac32x+1\) and \(y=\frac32x+7\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activity 4.10.1 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answers are \(y=-\frac32x+1\) and \(y=\frac32x+7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The linear function \(f(x)=x\) has a vertical stretch of 3, a vertical reflection, and a vertical shift down 4. Which of the following is the new function?

Correct! \(f(x)=-3x-4\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.10.2–4.10.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(f(x)=-3x-4\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The linear function \(f(x)=x\) has a vertical compression of \(\frac13\) and a vertical shift up 2. Which of the following is the new function?

Correct! \(f(x)=\frac13x+2\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.10.2–4.10.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(f(x)=\frac13x+2\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the equation of the function graphed?

Correct! \(y=-\frac34x+7\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.10.1–4.10.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(y=-\frac34x+7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. The linear function \(f(x)=x\) has a vertical compression of \(\frac13\) and a vertical shift down 2. Which of the following is the new function?

Correct! \(f(x)=2x - \frac13\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.10.2–4.10.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(f(x)=2x - \frac13\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 4.10.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Use slope-intercept form and transformations to graph linear functions.
  • Recognize the shifts made to a parent linear function to form another linear function.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 4.10.1: Graphing Linear Functions
    • In this activity, you reviewed how to graph linear functions using slope-intercept form. You looked at how different slopes and \(y\)-intercepts changed the graphs.
  • 4.10.2: Vertical Shifts
    • In this activity, you explored how changing the \(y\)-intercept causes a vertical shift of a linear function.
  • 4.10.2: Self Check
  • 4.10.3: Vertical Stretches and Compressions
    • In this activity, you explored how changing the slope causes vertical stretches, compressions, and reflections.
  • 4.10.3: Self Check
  • 4.10.4: Graphing Using Transformations
    • In this activity, you matched linear functions in slope-intercept form with their corresponding lines on a graph.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 4.10.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
